Award.AwardTitle: The Role of Peeling in Interfacial Engineering

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
The research objective of this grant is to determine if the conformation of a single polymer molecule on a surface can be accurately determined using the scanning probe microscope. This objective will be achieved by synthesizing alternating block copolymers comprised of well-defined surface affinities and molecular structures, imaging these molecules adsorbed onto a variety of surfaces, and then using dynamic force spectroscopy to repeatedly adsorb and detach the molecule from each of these surfaces. Correlation of the forces required to detach the molecule from a given surface with its molecular composition and structure will enable identification of the three-dimensional polymer?s interfacial structure.

If successful, this interdisciplinary collaborative effort will lead to a better understanding of how polymeric coatings interact with underlying surfaces and improved control over the interfacial properties of materials. Understanding the adsorption, desorption and conformation of polymers on substrates is extremely important in defining colloidal material interactions. Colloidal interactions are important in biomass conversion into biofuels, oil recovery, mining, food processing, papermaking, and water treatment. This interdisciplinary project involves students from under-represented groups and faculty from chemistry, chemical engineering and mechanical engineering working together to meet the research goals. Multiple undergraduate and graduate courses in the Schools of Chemistry & Biochemistry, Chemical & Biomolecular Engineering, and Mechanical Engineering at Georgia Tech will be enhanced.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The interaction of nanoscale objects with smooth surfaces is a very challenging phenomena to model. Even when the objects are fairly simple, such as carbon nanotubes in conformal contact with smooth flat substrates, the geometry of the deformations and the strength of the adhesion is complicated due to poorly understood contact forces.  When the nanoscale objects themselves have complicated structure or geometry, such as DNS molecules or nanocoils, the situation is more complicated. The use of an Atomic Force Microscope (AFM) to position nanotubes and long molecules onto chemically treated surfaces and to pull them off in a controlled fashion is one way in which we can learn much more about the nature of this complicated interaction. In particular, "peeling studies," using different types of structures can be a powerful way to improve our understanding of how contact, slip, and rupture occurs in the bonds between the nanotube and the substrate. This study used physical measurements with an AFM to simultaneously monitor the force, displacement, and the vibrational characteristics (natural frequencies) of the system as the peeling process was unfolding. The results of these experiments were compared to analytical models of simple nanotube elastic models. The study also used finite-element models to simulate the contact and peeling of more complicated nanoscale objects. In particular, nanoloops were modeled using thin planar beam elements and with attractive forces modeled using nonlinear springs.

 

Many engineering systems and man-made products and processes depend critically on knowing and predicting the adhesive forces between nanofibers and surfaces. For example, the development of surfaces that have the ability to repel water, dirt, or bacteria and other microbes, may profit from knowing how tightly the nanofibers and molecules will coat the surface. This research study has created methods of measurement and of simulation to aid in this endeavor. It has also uncovered new ways of proceeding in the future so that nanoengineered coatings can someday become a well understood and process.
